thread.title: Oilers' D-men lead way in snapping Panthers' 5-game win streak
thread.title_full: Oilers' D-men lead way in snapping Panthers' 5-game win streak

author: cbc
title: Oilers' D-men lead way in snapping Panthers' 5-game win streak
text:
Kris Russell scored the third goal of the night by Edmonton's defencemen with 7:58 left, lifting the Oilers over Florida 4-3 on Wednesday to snap the Panthers' five-game winning streak.
Russell's goal was his first since Feb. 11, 2016, when he played for Calgary. He went goalless in his first 48 games with the Oilers.

RUSSELL THE MUSCLE! ðŸ’ª #EDMvsFLA pic.twitter.com/IT4yTnEHXw 
â€” @EdmontonOilers Fellow defencemen Oscar Klefbom and Eric Gryba also scored for Edmonton, as did forward Ryan Nugent-Hopkins. Connor McDavid, who came into the night leading the NHL scoring race, had an assist on Russell's goal.
Aleksander Barkov, Colton Sceviour and Jonathan Marchessault scored for Florida. Keith Yandle had two assists for the Panthers, giving him 400 points for his career.
Cam Talbot stopped 31 shots for the Oilers, who have won their last eight games at Florida â€” last losing on the Panthers' ice in 2002. James Reimer made 31 saves for the Panthers, who just completed a 5-0-0 road trip.
The Panthers trailed for 93 seconds on their five-game road trip. They trailed for the final 14:42 of the first period alone in this one, after Klefbom's unassisted goal opened the scoring.
From there, the trend of the night emerged: Edmonton would lead, and Florida would come back. It worked three times â€” but not a fourth.
Florida knotted the game on a power-play goal from Barkov 21 seconds into the second period. Gryba made it 2-1 midway through the second, only to have Sceviour answer five minutes later. And just when it seemed like Edmonton would take a 3-2 lead into the third period, the Oilers quickly gave the advantage back.
Edmonton Oilers centre Ryan Nugent-Hopkins scores a goal against Florida Panthers goalie James Reimer during the second period on Wednesday. (Lynne Sladky/The Associated Press)
Nugent-Hopkins' goal off a rebound with 1:01 left in the second gave Edmonton its third lead, but Matt Hendricks was whistled for holding five seconds later. And just as it did to start the period, Florida finished the second by cashing in on the man advantage â€” with Marchessault scoring with four seconds left to send the teams into the final 20 minutes tied yet again.
